title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,

snippet: Only look, father, how his bonny wee dog Princy leads him through among the briars and branches ; and how, with his staff feeling round in all directions, the auld man, without a single stumble, is making his way along the wood ! See now ; he kens folk are near at hand, for Princy is beginning to cock up his ears and bark ; so Sandy has taken his seat on a stump, and now for his fiddle ! Ay, you'll hear him singing too — hush — it is puir Tanna- hill's sang, wi' Mr Smith's music — ' Jessie, the Flower o' Dunblane.' "

In thatof 1567 the Archbishop of St Andrews, the Bishops of Dunkeld, GaUoway,Dunblane, Brechin, Orkney, Aberdeen, and Ross, were present ; andeven in 1568, after Protestantism was established, they had not beenejected, for we find the Bishop of Moray (Hepburn) in his place, andchosen to be one of the Lords ofthe Articles on the Spiritual side, togetherwith the apostate Bishop of Orkney. — E.]

title: We four.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The horse, at the head of the first column, wereadvancing, according to their orders, when a lameboy, running as fast as his infirmity would permithim, stated to the Master of Sinclair, who commanded the advance, that he was sent by the wifeof the Laird of Kippendavie, whose husband wasin the Jacobite army, to tell the Earl of Mar thatthe Duke of Argyle was in the act of marchingthrough Dunblane.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The rest of the army, commanded by Mar inperson, with the assistance of General Hamilton,followed the advanced division ; and it was settledthat the rearguard should march only as far as Ardoch, while the vanguard should push forward asfar as the town of Dunblane, where they had quartered on their former march from Perth, eightmiles to the west of Ardoch, where the rear wasto halt.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: About a mile and a-half to the east of Dunblane, the battle of Sheriffmuir, or Dunblane, was fought in 1715,between the Earl of Mar (for the Chevalier St. George, or the Pretender) and the royal forces under the Duke of Argyle, a stone, called"The Battle Stone," marking the scene of the conflict.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles

snippet: There are a number of interesting monumentshere, one of which is a sculptured figure of Michael Ochiltree, a Bishopof the See in the fifteenth century; another of the bishops of Dunblanewas Archbishop Leighton.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: The railway, on leaving the Bridge of Allan, skirts the river Allan, and,passing by a tunnel through the grounds of Kippercross, reaches theold-fashioned village of Dunblane, which contains a cathedral, one ofthe few specimens of Gothic architecture which immeasurably excelsthose of both Melrose and Roslin in beauty of proportion and depthand force of moulding.

title: Varieties in Prose
author: Allingham, William
snippet: 'Jessie, the Flower o' Dunblane,' on the other hand,though not first-rate, is natural and pleasing, and the sunsetting o'er the lofty Ben Lomond is a piece of landscapetruth that must come home to every one at Dunblane andother places eastward of that rocky pyramid.
